Proteins

Protein time scales

A horizontally scrollable time axis for protein motions, from femtosecond bond vibrations up to hours-long turnover. Times are placed on a logarithmic scale in seconds, similar in spirit to the “1-pixel solar system”.

All images are optional – here we just show markers and text. You can later add GIFs or small icons for each process. Scroll to the right to see slower motions.

Bond vibrations
10⁻¹⁵–10⁻¹³ s
Ultrafast stretching and bending of covalent bonds and angles.
Side-chain librations
10⁻¹³–10⁻¹¹ s
Very local motions around rotatable bonds; largely averaged out in most experimental observables.
Fast side-chain flips
10⁻¹²–10⁻¹⁰ s
χ-angle jumps and methyl rotations that contribute to NMR order parameters.
Backbone wobbling
10⁻¹¹–10⁻⁹ s
Small-amplitude motions of backbone atoms within a local minimum, sampled well in short MD simulations.
Loop breathing
10⁻⁹–10⁻⁷ s
Opening/closing of loops or termini that modulate access to active sites or glycans.
Secondary-structure shifts
10⁻⁸–10⁻⁵ s
Helix–coil or β-structure rearrangements, often enriched in dynamically ambiguous regions.
Domain motions
10⁻⁶–10⁻² s
Hinge or shear motions between domains, relevant for allostery and binding but difficult to fully converge.
Conformational exchange
10⁻³–10⁰ s
Exchange between long-lived conformers; shows up as line broadening or relaxation dispersion in NMR.
Binding / unbinding
10⁻²–10² s
Association and dissociation of ligands, glycans and partners; kinetics that connect dynamics to affinity.
Folding & turnover
10²–10⁴ s
Slow processes such as folding after synthesis, degradation, trafficking and large-scale remodeling.

Scroll horizontally to traverse the scale. Positions are schematic but log-spaced in seconds, emphasizing how protein motions span many orders of magnitude in time.
